instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2850: What is 820-2850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.C9560: What is C9560? Tantalum capacitor on 820-2850 logic board that often dies and causes intermittent power to framebuffer PP1V8R1V55_S0GPU_ISNS and PP1V8R1V55_S0GPU_ISNS_R rail, causing GPU kernel panics. Replace with non-tantalum if machine is having random black screen or kernel panics.
definitions.LCD_BKLT_EN: What is LCD_BKLT_EN? This is an enable signal. Anytime you see “_EN”, it means when the voltage is high(3.3 volts), whatever it is going to is being turned on or enabled. Here, “LCD_BKLT” which stands for “LCD screen backlight” is being enabled. This signal usually goes to an LED driver used for creating a power rail for the LCD screen backlight, to tell it to turn on & create this rail. .
definitions.Q9706: What is Q9706? Q9706 takes PPBUS_G3H's vltage and sends it through to the backlight circuit. If Q9706 is not allowing PPBUS_G3H through, you will get no voltage on the backlight circuit. Q9706 is a P channel MOSFET, meaning power will flow through it when the voltage on the gate is lower than on the source. Look at pin 3. R9788 takes the 12.6v that is on the source and places it right on pin 3. This will set Q9706 to "off", and not allow it to pass power, as the voltage on the source and the gate are identical..

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight
threads.message:
had liquid damage, fixed everything else up to this point

replaced <CAPACITOR>C9560</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C7241</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C7282</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C7281</CAPACITOR>, L9000, <CAPACITOR>C9010</CAPACITOR>, F9800,<CAPACITOR>C9802</CAPACITOR>

<RESISTOR>R9808</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R9809</RESISTOR> but the last two are reading at ~100k in circuit instead of their proper values

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S0_LCDBKLT_FUSED</SIGNAL> 12.6V ok

<SIGNAL>PBUS_S0_LCDBKLT_EN_DIV</SIGNAL> reading 6.31V
at first it starts at proper 4.21V and then jumps up to the 6.31V

Is it <TRANSISTOR>Q9806</TRANSISTOR> or am I looking in the wrong place, the LVDS connector is questionable but seems to work.

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight
threads.message:
Voltages on pin 4, 8, 22, 23 of <CHIP>U9701</CHIP>?

Voltage drop to ground on <CAPACITOR>C9797</CAPACITOR>?

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight
threads.message: Just to clarify, is <TRANSISTOR>Q9806</TRANSISTOR> not opening? Why are we looking at <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S0_LCDBKLT_EN_DIV</SIGNAL>? If it is not opening, what are <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>BKLT_PLT_RST_L</SIGNAL> ?

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PBUS_S0_LCDBKLT_EN_L</SIGNAL>  3.42V
<SIGNAL>BKLT_PLT_RST_L</SIGNAL>  3.3V
<SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>  3.3V

<CHIP>U9701</CHIP>
pin 4 negligible mv
pin 8 3.3V
pin 22 and 23 both 4.96V

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight
[SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight
threads.message:
My vote is bad <TRANSISTOR>Q9807</TRANSISTOR> as well. It's dual N channel meaning if voltage on gate is equal/higher than source it should let power flow meaning tat if <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> & <SIGNAL>BKLT_PLT_RST_L</SIGNAL> are 3.3v than <SIGNAL>PBUS_S0_LCDBKLT_EN_L</SIGNAL> should be ground. 3.42v is not ground!

The voltage on pin 4 of <CHIP>U9701</CHIP> comes from the voltage divider of <RESISTOR>R9731</RESISTOR>/<RESISTOR>R9715</RESISTOR> whose power is sourced from <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S0_LCDBKLT_PW</SIGNAL> which comes from <TRANSISTOR>Q9806</TRANSISTOR> which will not open so long as <TRANSISTOR>Q9807</TRANSISTOR> is not opening and allowing the voltage divider of <RESISTOR>R9808</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R9809</RESISTOR> to drop <TRANSISTOR>Q9706</TRANSISTOR>'s gate voltage to ground. <TRANSISTOR>Q9706</TRANSISTOR> is a P channel and will open when voltage on gate is sufficiently lower than the source.

Replace <TRANSISTOR>Q9807</TRANSISTOR>!

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight
threads.message: I guess it was a typo, replace <TRANSISTOR>Q9807</TRANSISTOR>!!

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight
threads.message: No typo, good diagnosis! I agree with you. :)

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight
threads.message:
[QUOTE="larossmann, post: 16071"]My vote is bad <TRANSISTOR>Q9807</TRANSISTOR> as well. It's dual N channel meaning if voltage on gate is equal/higher than source it should let power flow meaning tat if <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> & <SIGNAL>BKLT_PLT_RST_L</SIGNAL> are 3.3v than <SIGNAL>PBUS_S0_LCDBKLT_EN_L</SIGNAL> should be ground. 3.42v is not ground!

The voltage on pin 4 of <CHIP>U9701</CHIP> comes from the voltage divider of <RESISTOR>R9731</RESISTOR>/<RESISTOR>R9715</RESISTOR> whose power is sourced from <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S0_LCDBKLT_PW</SIGNAL> which comes from <TRANSISTOR>Q9706</TRANSISTOR> which will not open so long as [COLOR=#FF0000]<TRANSISTOR>Q9707</TRANSISTOR>[/COLOR] is not opening and allowing the voltage divider of <RESISTOR>R9808</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R9809</RESISTOR> to drop <TRANSISTOR>Q9706</TRANSISTOR>'s gate voltage to ground. <TRANSISTOR>Q9706</TRANSISTOR> is a P channel and will open when voltage on gate is sufficiently lower than the source.

Replace [COLOR=#FF0000]<TRANSISTOR>Q9707</TRANSISTOR>![/COLOR][/QUOTE]


;)..........

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight
threads.message:
ok I did <TRANSISTOR>Q9807</TRANSISTOR> and <SIGNAL>PBUS_S0_LCDBKLT_EN_DIV</SIGNAL> stabilized properly at 4.21
<TRANSISTOR>Q9806</TRANSISTOR> was still reading nothing on left pins to inductor
did <TRANSISTOR>Q9806</TRANSISTOR> (and a jumper to the fuse since that line seemed unreliable) and now it looks like it's all good
